body.name: Cloud Paper Bamboo Facial Tissues - 4 Boxes of Eco-Friendly, 3-Ply Hypoallergenic Tissues, 100 Sheets per Box, FSC Certified, Plastic-Free Packaging, Soft & Gentle for Home Use
deliveryMessages: FREE delivery Monday, February 19 on orders shipped by Amazon over $35
Or fastest delivery Friday, February 16. Order within 6 hrs 30 mins
features: Eco-Conscious Comfort: Experience the softness and gentleness of Cloud Paper's 3-ply bamboo facial tissues, designed for the conscious consumer. Our tissues are crafted from sustainably sourced, FSC-certified bamboo, ensuring an eco-friendly choice for your home (FSC C041262).

Hypoallergenic Assurance: Prioritizing your health, our bamboo tissues are hypoallergenic and fragrance-free, making them suitable for all skin types, including sensitive skin. Safe and gentle for everyday use.

Perfect for Any Occasion: Whether you're managing allergies, freshening up, or dealing with the common cold, Cloud Paper's bamboo tissues are your go-to solution. Their strength and softness make them ideal for diverse uses, ensuring comfort and care in every sheet. Suitable for home, office, or on-the-go needs.
Versatile and Soft: Perfect for facial care, our bamboo tissues are soft yet durable, ideal for delicate skin. Use them for makeup removal, during colds, or for any gentle touch your skin requires.

Sustainable Packaging: Delivered in plastic-free packaging, our bamboo tissues represent our commitment to the environment. Choose Cloud Paper and contribute to a more sustainable world with each tissue used.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Environmental Friendly & Durable
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this item to be environmentally friendly. The tissues are rough, but durable & absorbs well. The tissues do not fall apart where your shots end up all over your hands. The tissues are thick enough that you can also reuse it if needed.My whole family ended up having a really bad cold and the tissues lasted us the 8+ weeks. My 2 & 5 year old do not mind the texture and during those 8+ weeks, no one got a raw nose like we have with the other tissue brands.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not too soft
reviews.reviewText: I wasn’t crazy about this item it was more rough than the usual Kleenex, that we have we use them, but I won’t be re-ordering

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I like these tissues and will order them again. I would recommend this product to anyone shopping for "Kleen-X" type tissues; they stay intact and don't come apart in your hands.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Bought these because other tissues create so much dust. These are a bit rougher, but I'll take that over extra house dust. Wish they were 2 ply rather than 3 - a little softer that way. Easy to peel 1 ply off and use separately. I will be buying again!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 1.0 out of 5 stars Bamboo products are not a "New" thing yet they keep raising the prices like they are
reviews.reviewText: If bamboo is SO much more readily available, renewable, and sustainable than trees, then why, after ALL these years, does it still cost some exuberant amount of money to get bamboo-made products? Bamboo sanitary products are NOT a new concept. We started buying bamboo products like TP and tissue paper many years ago (At least 6 years now). Firstly, bamboo is a graminaceous plant and it can grow up to 2 feet each day so there is a never-ending abundance of it, It never needs to be "cut down" just "cut back". Because so many companies are making bamboo products it's not like they ALL need to spend millions of dollars R&Ding how to produce/manufacture it anymore. With all the competition out there now, you would think these highly renewable products would be cheaper, not absurdly more, than products manufactured from destroying trees. If you want to change the world, let's start by acknowledging the greed of these companies first then, we'll talk about doing something GOOD for the planet, not the CEO's and their benefactor's pocketbooks. Till the world of greed changes, I am going to stick with what I can afford... tree-made products.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Like the tissues; don’t like the packaging.
reviews.reviewText: I like these tissues. I’ve used other brands of bamboo tissues, and these are fairly comparable for softness and strength (no bamboo tissues I’ve tried are comparable in softness to the softest paper tissues). I use multiple tissues a day, and do not find these tissues too rough, and they are strong enough, and have no odor.They are on the pricey side, but I decided to try them because they are one of the few bamboo tissue brands that I could find on Amazon that has paperboard, not plastic, packaging. I looked forward to being able to put the boxes into my paper and cardboard recycling.To my great disappointment, the paperboard packages the Cloud Paper tissues come in have a thin layer of plastic sealed to the top of the paperboard. And the packages are not labeled to indicate whether they are recyclable. Perhaps they *are* recyclable, but plastic that is intermingled in paper that is recycled makes low-quality recycled paper, and toxic substances can cling to plastic, which I believe would degrade the quality of plastic-contaminated recycled paper even more. The cardboard boxes that the tissue boxes are shipped in by Cloud Paper are also sealed with tape that appears to be a paper/plastic composite of some sort.Also disappointing: the ends of at least half of the tissue boxes are only partially sealed (some of the places where the overlapping ends of the boxes were glued together have separated), so if one plans to store unopened boxes in a cupboard that might be visited by bugs or spiders, those small critters would be able to crawl inside the unopened boxes and make nests in them, etc. So if the layer of plastic on the paperboard boxes is meant to protect the boxes from the elements, it’s not doing much to protect the tissues inside the boxes.Finally, I don’t like that Cloud Paper, based in Washington state according to its website, is opaque about where it is getting the bamboo the tissues are made of, let alone where the packaging materials come from. There is nothing on the boxes to indicate the source of the bamboo, nor is there even a mailing address for Cloud Paper. The company’s website says the bamboo comes from responsibly managed forests in areas where bamboo grows natively, which language just strikes me as coy. But the website also says there is no plastic in their packaging, and that the packaging is both recyclable and compostable. So what is the thin plastic layer sealed to the top of the tissue boxes’ paperboard? Is it plastic, even though the website says the packaging has no plastic, or is it some sort of very strong compostable film that is much stronger than compostable trash bags that start to degrade pretty quickly when they get wet? I’ve had a segment of the plastic top layer from one of the tissue boxes sitting in a bowl of water for over 1/2-hour, and it is not noticeably degrading. I don’t know what I should do with the boxes once they’re empty. The website says we can call Cloud Paper if we’re concerned about how to recycle their packaging, and I may do that. But I think the boxes should be labeled to indicate whether and how they are recyclable or compostable, and I think we shouldn’t have to call a supposedly eco-conscious company to find out how to dispose of their tissue boxes, and I think we should be able to trust what the company says on its website.I don’t plan to purchase Cloud Paper products again. Back to searching for another bamboo tissue brand that comes in actual recyclable paper or paperboard packages.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good value and pretty soft
reviews.reviewText: I was really happy with these tissues. They are a good value, you get so many boxes. They are pretty soft and aren't cheap or thin feeling. They don't have any lotions or scents in them and I like that they are totally plastic free and natural. Overall a good product, I will repurchase.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Nice bamboo tissues
reviews.reviewText: These are a bit softer than the Who Gives a Crap brand, and I like them better. It would be nice if I didn’t have to use two hands to pull out each tissue (one to hold the box and one to pull out the tissue), but regardless of the brand, I think this is a general limitation of using only cardboard for the box without a plastic film around the opening. And plastic-free is better for the environment. You might be able to use a decorative cover around the box to weight it down, but most covers are either square-shaped or designed for taller boxes than these. Either way, the box would probably flop around inside the cover. Maybe put something flat and heavy on the bottom of the cover so the box fits snugly (assuming the cover has a bottom on it). I might look on Etsy for someone to make me a cover with the right dimensions.Overall these tissues are competitive with other bamboo tissues. I would buy them again.
